ORDER
Service connection for posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is denied.
REMANDED
Entitlement to service connection for a psychiatric disorder other than PTSD, to include as secondary to service-connected fibromyalgia.
Entitlement to a total rating based on individual unemployability due to service-connected disability (TDIU).
FINDING OF FACT
There is no diagnosis of PTSD.
CONCLUSION OF LAW
The criteria for service connection for PTSD are not met.
REASONS AND BASES FOR FINDING AND CONCLUSION
The Veteran served on active duty from February 1976 to February 1980 and from August 1989 to August 1993.
This case comes before the Board of Veterans’ Appeals (Board) on appeal from rating decisions of the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) Regional Office (RO) in North Little Rock, Arkansas.
This case was most previously before the Board in February 2016.
In February 2014, the Veteran testified at a Travel Board Hearing before the undersigned VLJ.
Duties to Notify and Assist
Neither the Veteran nor his representative has raised any issues with the duty to notify or duty to assist.

See Scott v. McDonald, 789 F.3d 1375, 1381 (Fed. Cir. 2015) (holding that “the Board’s obligation to read filings in a liberal manner does not require the Board... to search the record and address procedural arguments when the veteran fails to raise them before the Board”); Dickens v. McDonald, 814 F.3d 1359, 1361 (Fed. Cir. 2016) (applying Scott to a duty to assist argument).
The Veteran offered testimony before the undersigned Veterans Law Judge at a Board hearing in February 2014.
The Board finds that all requirements for hearing officers have been met.
To the extent that any evidentiary deficiency was noted, the Board finds that it has been cured on remand.
The Board also finds that there has been compliance with the prior remand directives.
See Stegall v. West, 11 Vet. App. 268 (1998).
VA’s duties to notify and assist are met, and the Board will address the merits of the claim.
Laws and regulations
Service connection may be granted for a disability resulting from disease or injury incurred in or aggravated by active service.

To establish a right to compensation for a present disability, a Veteran must show: (1) the existence of a present disability; (2) in-service incurrence or aggravation of a disease or injury; and (3) a causal relationship between the present disability and the disease or injury incurred or aggravated during service- the so-called “nexus” requirement.
Holton v. Shinseki, 557 F.3d 1362, 1366 (Fed. Cir. 2009) (quoting Shedden v. Principi, 381 F.3d 1163, 1167 (Fed. Cir. 2004)).

Service connection may be granted for any disease initially diagnosed after discharge when all of the evidence, including that pertinent to service, establishes that the disease was incurred in service.

In addition, service connection for certain chronic diseases may be established on a presumptive basis by showing that the condition manifested to a degree of 10 percent or more within one year from the date of separation from service.

Although the disease need not be diagnosed within the presumption period, it must be shown, by acceptable lay or medical evidence, that there were characteristic manifestations of the disease to the required degree during that time.

For the showing of chronic disease in service, there is required a combination of manifestations sufficient to identify the disease entity, and sufficient observation to establish chronicity at the time.
If chronicity in service is not established, a showing of continuity of symptoms after discharge may support the claim.

Service connection for PTSD requires: (1) medical evidence establishing a diagnosis of the disorder; (2) credible supporting evidence that the claimed in-service stressor occurred; and (3) a link established by medical evidence, between current symptoms and an in-service stressor.

There are several avenues to document an in-service stressor, other than obtaining verification from the Joint Services Records Research Center (JSRRC) or other government records repository:  an in-service PTSD diagnosis with lay testimony; combat service with lay testimony; prisoner of war status with lay testimony; lay evidence of personal assault with appropriate corroboration; and a stressor related to Veteran's fear of hostile military or terrorist activity, with appropriate medical evidence.

Lay evidence may establish an alleged stressor may where: 1) the stressor is related to the Veteran's fear of hostile military or terrorist activity; 2) a VA psychiatrist, VA psychologist, or VA-contracted psychiatrist or psychologist, confirms that the claimed stressor is adequate to support a diagnosis of PTSD and that the Veteran's symptoms are related to the claimed stressor; 3) the stressor is consistent with the places, types, and circumstances of the Veteran's service; and 4) there is no clear and convincing evidence to the contrary.
See Stressor Determinations for Posttraumatic Stress Disorder, 75 Fed. Reg. 39,843, 39,852.

Fear of hostile military or terrorist activity occurs where a veteran experienced, witnessed, or was confronted with an event or circumstance that involved actual or threatened death or serious injury, or a threat to the physical integrity of the veteran or others, such as from an actual or potential improvised explosive device; vehicle-imbedded explosive device; incoming artillery, rocket, or mortar fire; grenade; small arms fire, including suspected sniper fire; or attack upon friendly military aircraft, and the veteran's response to the event or circumstance involved a psychological or psycho-physiological state of fear, helplessness, or horror.
See Stressor Determinations for Posttraumatic Stress Disorder, 75 Fed. Reg. 39,843, 39,852.
The threshold question in any claim seeking service connection is whether the veteran, in fact, has the disability for which service connection is sought.
McClain v. Nicholson, 21 Vet. App. 319, 321 (2007).
In the absence of proof of a current disability, service connection is not warranted.
Brammer v. Derwinski, 3 Vet. App. 223, 225 (1992).
Analysis
At the February 2014 Board hearing the Veteran stated that one of his PTSD stressors during the Gulf War involved a chemical attack that tuned out to be a false alarm.
Another stressor involved witnessing "many people who got run over by a bus."
The Veteran indicated that he had been attending twice weekly VA PTSD classes for about two years.

In a January 2018 response, the Defense Personnel Records Information Retrieval System (DPRIS) stated that upon review of the Veteran’s unit history, it was documented that in January 1991,” due to the Scud alerts and activities, elements from the Brigade put on their chemical protective gear.”
The Veteran’s service treatment records indicate that he affirmed sleeping problems, depression, and nervous troubles at the time of separation from his second period of service.
Thus, the evidence of record demonstrates a verified stressor during service and psychiatric symptoms during service.
The next issue is whether there is resulting PTSD.
The Board finds that there is not a current disability.
See Holton, 557 F.3d at 1366; 38 C.F.R. § 3.303(d).
A February 2018 VA examination was conducted upon a review of the claims file and interview of the Veteran.
The examiner ultimately determined that there was not PTSD diagnosis.
The examiner noted review of the medical records, to include prior PTSD diagnoses of record.
The examiner also noted that VA psychiatric examinations in 2010, 2011, and 2013 found there was no diagnosis of PTSD.
The examiner addressed that although SSA records and VA records noted PTSD, the records were either devoid of symptoms or did not relate the PTSD to any identifiable stressor.
A November 2011 VA psychiatrist had noted that she was “unsure that the Veteran had PTSD,” and “rule-out” PTSD was carried on many of the VA treatment records.

The February 2018 VA examiner stated that many of the PTSD diagnoses in the Veteran’s available medical records were apparently made based on the Veteran’s self-report of PTSD history, or based on the note writer’s knowledge that the Veteran was in therapy for PTSD.
The 2018 examiner indicated that the Veteran did not have a diagnosis of PTSD that conformed to DSM-5 criteria based on that day’s evaluation.

In particular, the examiner indicated that the Veteran’s PTSD symptoms did not meet Criterion D (negative alterations in cognitions and mood associated with the traumatic events), criterion in this section met.

The Board accords this opinion significant probative value as it is based upon review of the relevant medical and lay evidence, addresses contrary evidence of record and contains a full supporting explanation.
As noted by the examiner, the PTSD diagnoses in the record are less thorough and as such, are not accorded probative value.
Thus, there is no PTSD diagnosis.
In reaching this decision the Board considered the doctrine of reasonable doubt, however, as the preponderance of the evidence is against the Veteran’s claim, the doctrine is not for application.
Gilbert v. Derwinski, 1 Vet. App. 49 (1990).
REASONS FOR REMAND
Regarding the issue of service connection for psychiatric disability other than PTSD, remand is required for an adequate VA examination.
Where VA provides the veteran with an examination in a service connection claim, the examination must be adequate.
Barr v. Nicholson, 21 Vet. App. 303, 311 (2007).
A February 2018 VA examination was conducted.
The VA examiner indicated that the Veteran's current symptoms did not meet the diagnostic criteria for any mental disorder.
VA treatment records, however, dated after that time (including March 2018) have revealed current psychiatric diagnoses, including depression and anxiety disorder.
Another VA examination is needed.
As for the issue of entitlement to a TDIU, remand is also required.
Issues are inextricably intertwined and must be considered together when a decision concerning one could have a significant impact on the other.
Harris v. Derwinski, 1 Vet. App. 180, 183 (1991).
As TDIU is predicated on the presence of service-connected disabilities, the two issues are intertwined.
The matter is REMANDED for the following action:
Contact the appropriate VA Medical Center and obtain and associate with the claims file all outstanding records of treatment on and after July 18, 2018.
If any requested records are not available, or the search for any such records otherwise yields negative results, that fact must clearly be documented in the claims file.
Efforts to obtain these records must continue until it is determined that they do not exist or that further attempts to obtain them would be futile.
The non-existence or unavailability of such records must be verified and this should be documented for the record.
Required notice must be provided to the Veteran and her representative.
Contact the Veteran and afford him the opportunity to identify by name, address and dates of treatment or examination any relevant medical records.

Subsequently, and after securing the proper authorizations where necessary, make arrangements to obtain all the records of treatment or examination from all the sources listed by the Veteran which are not already on file.
All information obtained must be made part of the file.

All attempts to secure this evidence must be documented in the claims file, and if, after making reasonable efforts to obtain named records, they are not able to be secured, provide the required notice and opportunity to respond to the Veteran and his representative.
After any additional records are associated with the claims file, provide the Veteran with the appropriate examination to determine the etiology of any current psychiatric disorder other than PTSD.
The claims file must be made available to and reviewed by the examiner.
Any indicated tests and studies must be accomplished and all clinical findings must be reported in detail and correlated to a specific diagnosis.
An explanation for all opinions expressed must be provided.
First, the examiner must identify all current psychiatric disorders other than PTSD.
If depression and/or anxiety disorder are not diagnosed, a full explanation must be provided that addresses the prior diagnoses of record.

Second, for each such disorder, the examiner must state whether it is at least as likely as not (a 50 percent or greater probability) that the disorder manifested in or is otherwise related to the Veteran’s military service.

Third, the examiner must state whether it is at least as likely as not (a 50 percent or greater probability) that each non-PTSD psychiatric disorder was caused by or aggravated by his service-connected fibromyalgia and right shoulder disabilities, to include pain from those disabilities.

Notify the Veteran that it is his responsibility to report for any scheduled examination and to cooperate in the development of the claims, and that the consequences for failure to report for a VA examination without good cause may include denial of the claims.

ORDER
Entitlement to service connection for an acquired psychiatric disorder, claimed as posttraumatic stress disorder (PSTD), is denied.
FINDINGS OF FACT
The preponderance of the evidence of record is against finding that the Veteran has had PTSD or any other psychiatric disorder at any time during or approximate to the pendency of the claim.
CONCLUSION OF LAW
The criteria for service connection for an acquired psychiatric disorder are not met.
REASONS AND BASES FOR FINDING AND CONCLUSION
The Veteran served on active duty from October 1967 to November 1970, which included service in Korea from March 1968 to March 1969.

Although the Veteran initially requested a video-conference hearing before the Board in his formal appeal, he later withdrew his request for a hearing in an August 2016 statement pursuant to 38 C.F.R. § 20.704(e).
Additionally, even though the Veteran filed a claim for PTSD, VA treatment records from 2010 and 2011 contain a psychiatric diagnosis of an adjustment disorder with depressed mood.

Thus, the Board has recharacterized the issue of entitlement to service connection for PTSD to more broadly include entitlement to service connection for an acquired psychiatric disability pursuant to Clemons v. Shinseki, 23 Vet. App. 1 (2009) (holding that when a claimant makes a claim, he is seeking service connection for symptoms regardless of how those symptoms are diagnosed or labeled)
Service connection for an acquired psychiatric disorder is denied.
The Veteran asserts that he is entitled to service connection for PTSD, claiming that he developed anger and stress as a result of his service.
See September 2015 notice of disagreement.

He identified three stressful events that occurred when he was stationed in the demilitarized zone (DMZ) in Korea:  (1) he heard broadcasted loudspeaker announcements with the names and addresses of himself and his family; (2) a truck of soldiers were ambushed and killed; and (3) while in his foxhole, enemies would sneak around at night and turn soldiers’ claymore mines around to face the soldiers.
Three general requirements for establishing service connection for PTSD are outlined in 38 C.F.R. § 3.304(f).

Service connection for PTSD requires medical evidence diagnosing the condition in accordance with 38 C.F.R. § 4.125(a), which requires a diagnosis conforming with the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition (DSM-5); a link, established by medical evidence, between current symptoms and an in-service stressor; and credible supporting evidence that the claimed in-service stressor occurred.

In cases such as this, where a stressor claimed by a veteran is related to fear of hostile military or terrorist activity, if a VA psychiatrist or psychologist confirms the stressors is adequate to support a diagnosis of PTSD and that the veteran’s symptoms are related to the claimed stressor, in the absence of clear and convincing evidence to the contrary, and provided the claimed stressor is consistent with the places, types, and circumstances of service, lay testimony alone may establish the occurrence of the claimed in-service stressor.
For disabilities other than PTSD, generally, service connection may be granted for disability resulting from disease or injury incurred in or aggravated by active service.

The three-element test for service connection requires evidence of:  (1) a current disability; (2) in-service incurrence or aggravation of a disease or injury; and (3) a causal relationship between the current disability and the in-service disease or injury.
Shedden v. Principi, 381 F.3d 1163, 1166 -67 (Fed. Cir. 2004).
The question for the Board is whether the Veteran has a current disability that began during service or is at least as likely as not related to an in-service injury, event, or disease.

After carefully reviewing the record, the Board concludes that the Veteran does not have a current diagnosis of PTSD, or any other psychiatric disorder, and has not had one at any time during the pendency of the claim or recent to the filing of the claim.
Romanowsky v. Shinseki, 26 Vet. App. 289, 294 (2013); McClain v. Nicholson, 21 Vet. App. 319, 321 (2007).
The Board acknowledges, that prior to the appeal period in September 2010, the Veteran “sought mental health treatment to cope with recent separation from wife who left him for ‘anger problems.’”
See September 2010 VA treatment report.
According to the initial psychological evaluation, the VA doctor, co-signed by a psychiatrist, assessed “[a]djustment disorder with depressed mood.”
However, the condition was noted as “improving” during October 2010, November 2010, December 2010, and January 2011 VA treatment reports.
When the Veteran reported for his April 2011 mental health consultation, the VA clinician noted an impression of “[a]djustment disorder with depressed mood, resolved.”
Id. (emphasis added).
At that time, the Veteran reported “doing well since his last visit [in January 2011].  He and his wife reunited.”
See April 2011 VA treatment record.
Additionally, although there were still flares of temper at times, “he feels [t]his coming on and calms himself.”
Id.

Significantly, the VA clinician explained that the Veteran “does not appear to require further monitoring by mental health services at this time.  It is also his stated desire to discontinue being seen at this time. . . .  We will terminate his mental healthcare at this time.  I reminded [him] that he can return to the VA M[ental] H[ealth] C[linic] in the future if he feels that he needs to be seen again for any reason.”).
Id.
Thus, this condition was noted to have resolved more than three years before filed his claim for VA benefits for PTSD.
In looking at the evidence of record after April 2011, VA treatment records suggest no recurrence.

See May 2013 VA treatment report (review of psychiatric system revealed “no anxiety or depression”); June 2013 VA treatment report (noting a negative screen for PTSD); July 2014 VA treatment report (noting a negative screen for depression).

Significantly, the Veteran underwent a VA psychiatric examination in August 2015 in conjunction with his claim for PTSD, which found that the Veteran did not meet the criteria for a current diagnosis.
The examiner concluded that the “Veteran does not have a mental disorder that conforms with DSM-5 criteria,” and that there was “[n]o mental disorder diagnosis.”
See August 2015 VA examination report.

In conjunction with the August 2015 examination, the examiner considered the Veteran’s three identified stressors and noted his complaints that “he is often angry and has verbal outbursts one or two times per month ‘over little things,’” his reports of chronic irritability after service, and being uncomfortable in crowds amongst other reported complaints.
Id.
The examiner explained that his service in the DMZ, although relating to a fear of hostile military or terrorist activity, was insufficient to support a diagnosis of PTSD.
Id.
His reported irritability after service “appeared to be more consistent with a partner relational problem than relating to past stressors.”
Id.
It was also noted that “no other indicators of hypervigilance were reported, and crowd avoidance was not described as causing significant distress or impairment.”
Id.
Despite the Veteran’s anger and other reported complaints, the VA examiner concluded, “Overall, report of symptoms does not suggest the presence of any mental disorder at this time.”

Id.  (Emphasis added) (also noting “His score of 23 on the BDI-II is indicative of moderate depression, but symptoms described in the interview did not suggest the presence of a depressive disorder” and “[i]tems endorsed on the PCL were below a range supporting a diagnosis of PTSD.”).
Although the Veteran believes he has a current diagnosis of PTSD, he is not competent to provide a diagnosis in this case.
The issue is medically complex, as psychiatric diagnoses require specialized medical education and the application of symptoms to the complicated diagnostic criteria of the DSM-5.
Jandreau v. Nicholson, 492 F.3d 1372, 1377, 1377 n.4 (Fed. Cir. 2007).
Consequently, the Board gives more probative weight to the competent medical evidence.

To the extent that the Veteran’s representative has suggested that a new VA examination should be obtained with a new examiner, the Board finds that the existing August 2015 VA examination and opinion are adequate.
The opinion was provided after a review of the claims file and is supported by a thorough rationale that accurately contemplates the Veteran's psychiatric history.

First, to the extent that the representative asserted that “the examiner listed only one stressor and listed it as “Korean DMZ deployment,” the Board notes that all three specific stressors were identified by the examiner in the “other significant military history” portion of the examination as follows:
Koreans “blared out” information about the American troops at night over loudspeakers as a means of intimidating them.
This information included soldiers’ names and the names and addresses of their family members.
Koreans would reposition claymore mines (turning them 180 degrees) during the night, also as a means of intimidating the Americans.
The mines were a few feet away from American soldiers, including veteran.
The Koreans repeatedly did this without setting off warning flares attached to trip wires.
Veteran received word that some soldiers (whom he did not know) were killed in an ambush by Koreans.
The truck in which they were riding was “shot up” with small arms fire.
Veteran did not witness the event.
See August 2015 examination report.
Ultimately, however, the examiner expressly concluded, “These events, though stressful, do not meet criterion A for PTSD.”
Regardless, it is clear from the report that the VA examiner considered all three of the Veteran’s reported stressors.

Next, to the extent that the representative states service-connected disabilities “more likely than not contribute to his mental health conditions to include depression” and suggests that the Veteran “should be evaluated and considered for service connection of mental health conditions to include depression secondary to his service-connected [disabilities],” the Board emphasizes that existing examination report concluded that that the Veteran did not have any psychiatric disability
Therefore, an opinion on secondary service connection is not warranted because the threshold criteria of a current disability has not been established.

Instead, the Board finds the existing August 2015 examiner’s opinion to be sufficient because it is based on an accurate medical history, it provides an explanation that contains an ultimate conclusion that there is no current psychiatric disability, and the examiner provides supporting data for that conclusion.
Nieves-Rodriguez v. Peake, 22 Vet. App. 295, 304 (2008).
For these reasons, the Board finds that the August 2015 VA opinion is entitled to the most probative weight.
As the preponderance of the evidence establishes that the Veteran does not have a diagnosis of PTSD or any other psychiatric diagnosis during the appeal period, service connection must be denied.
H.M. WALKER
Veterans Law Judge
Board of Veterans’ Appeals
Attorney for the Board K.Gielow, Counsel
Citation Nr: 19148674
Decision Date: 06/21/19Archive Date: 06/21/19
DOCKET NO. 16-46 455
DATE:June 21, 2019
ORDER
Entitlement to service connection for an acquired psychiatric disorder, claimed as posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD), anxiety disorder, and major depressive disorder, is granted.
FINDING OF FACT
Resolving reasonable doubt in the Veteran’s favor, his acquired psychiatric disorder is at least as likely as not related to his military service.
CONCLUSION OF LAW
The criteria for entitlement to service connection for an acquired psychiatric disorder have been met.
REASONS AND BASES FOR FINDING AND CONCLUSION
The Veteran served on active duty from April 1969 to April 1971.
This matter comes before the Board of Veterans' Appeals (Board) on appeal from a July 2016 rating decision of the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) Regional Office (RO).
In January 2019 the Veteran testified at a videoconference hearing before the undersigned Veterans Law Judge.
A copy of the transcript is associated with the evidentiary record.

The scope of a mental health disability claim includes any mental disability that may reasonably be encompassed by the appellant’s description of the claim, reported symptoms, and the other information of record.
Clemons v. Shinseki, 23 Vet. App. 1 (2009).

Thus, the Board has recharacterized the psychiatric claim on appeal to entitlement to service connection for an acquired psychiatric disorder, to include PTSD, anxiety disorder, and major depressive disorder.
Entitlement to service connection for an acquired psychiatric disorder.
Legal Criteria

Generally, to establish a right to compensation for a present disability a veteran must show: (1) a present disability; (2) an in-service incurrence or aggravation of a disease or injury; and (3) a causal relationship between the present disability and the disease or injury incurred or aggravated during service.
Shedden v. Principi, 381 F.3d 1163, 1167 (Fed. Cir. 2004).
For compensation purposes, there are particular requirements for establishing PTSD in 38 C.F.R. § 3.304(f) that are separate from those for establishing service connection generally.
Arzio v. Shinseki, 602 F.3d 1343, 1347 (Fed. Cir. 2010).

Establishing service connection for PTSD requires: (1) medical evidence diagnosing PTSD; (2) credible supporting evidence that the claimed in-service stressor actually occurred; and (3) medical evidence of a link between current symptomatology and the claimed in-service stressor.
38 C.F.R. § 3.304(f); see also Cohen v. Brown, 10 Vet. App. 128 (1997).

If a PTSD stressor claimed by a veteran is related to the veteran's fear of hostile military or terrorist activity and a VA psychiatrist or psychologist, or a psychiatrist or psychologist with whom VA has contracted, confirms that the claimed stressor is adequate to support a diagnosis of posttraumatic stress disorder and that the Veteran's symptoms are related to the claimed stressor, in the absence of clear and convincing evidence to the contrary, and provided the claimed stressor is consistent with the places, types, and circumstances of the Veteran's service, the Veteran's lay testimony alone may establish the occurrence of the claimed in-service stressor.

Under 38 C.F.R. § 3.304(f)(3), "fear of hostile military or terrorist activity" means that a veteran experienced, witnessed, or was confronted with an event or circumstance that involved actual or threatened death or serious injury, or a threat to the physical integrity of the veteran or others, such as from an actual or potential improvised explosive device; vehicle-imbedded explosive device; incoming artillery, rocket, or mortar fire; grenade; small arms fire, including suspected sniper fire; or attack upon friendly military aircraft, and the veteran's response to the event or circumstance involved a psychological or psycho-physiological state of fear, helplessness, or horror.
When there is an approximate balance of positive and negative evidence regarding any issue material to the determination of a matter, VA shall resolve reasonable doubt in favor of the claimant.
38 U.S.C. § 5107; 38 C.F.R. § 3.102; Gilbert v. Derwinski, 1 Vet. App. 49 (1990).
To deny a claim on its merits, the evidence must preponderate against the claim.
Alemany v. Brown, 9 Vet. App. 518 (1996).
Analysis
The Veteran contends that he is entitled to service connection for PTSD based on in-service stressors.
See January 2019 Hearing Transcript.

Based on the evidence of record, and resolving reasonable doubt in favor of the Veteran, the Board finds that entitlement to service connection for an acquired psychiatric disorder has been established.
Consistent with the Veteran’s contentions, the record establishes that the Veteran has been diagnosed with PTSD, major depressive disorder, and an anxiety disorder.
See July 2016 Medical Treatment Record- Government Facility at 7.
The record shows that the Veteran has received treatment including group therapy and medication for his acquired psychiatric disorders since at least June 2013.
See October 2016 Medical Treatment Record- Government Facility at 6; see also March 2017 Medical Treatment Record- Government Facility, August 2018 CAPRI, February 2019 CAPRI.
Further, the record establishes that the Veteran has consistently reported in-service stressors of the death of a friend and fellow soldier, mortar attacks and sniper attacks in service.
See October 2016 Medical Treatment Record- Government Facility at 11.
In May 2016, the Veteran reported being stationed near a major airfield and near two to three ammo dumps, and stated that this area received a lot of enemy mortar fire.
The Board concludes that the Veteran’s reports are consistent with his service.
His military personnel records reflect that from November 1969 to November 1970, he participated in operations against hostile forces in DaNang, Republic of Vietnam.
This appears to meet the definition of 38 C.F.R. § 3.304(f)(3), “fear of hostile military or terrorist activity.”
The next question is whether a psychiatrist or psychologist confirms that the claimed stressor is adequate to support a diagnosis of PTSD.

There is evidence for and against the claim that the Veteran has PTSD.  The Veteran’s entitlement to service connection for an acquired psychiatric disorder is supported by the opinions of the Veteran’s treating clinicians.
In an April 2014 statement, the Veteran’s psychologist J.T. reported that the Veteran began treatment for PTSD in June 2013, due to the Veteran experiencing traumas when serving in Vietnam.
The traumas included experiencing losing a close friend, being rocketed and mortared, fearing he would die when guarding a fuel dump that was hit, and being sniped at while out retrieving trucks.
The Veteran’s treatment consisted of weekly outpatient group therapy sessions.
The clinician reported that the Veteran’s symptoms included daily intrusive memories, frequent nightmares, flashbacks, hyper arousal, avoiding people and difficulty trusting other.
See March 2016 Medical Treatment Record- Non-Government Facility at 2.

Similarly, in January 2016, psychologist L.H. reported that the Veteran continued to attend group therapy for his PTSD and major depression due to experiencing repetitive traumas while serving in Vietnam.

The clinician reported the Veteran’s symptoms included hyper arousal, disturbed sleep, isolation from other, extremely low frustration tolerance, reactivity to others, poor concentration and difficulty staying on task.

The Veteran’s reported combat experiences included the loss of a close friend while “in-country,” daily or near daily rocket and mortar attacks due to his location directly adjacent to two large ammunition storage areas during his entire tour, and experiencing sniper attacks and night penetration of his compound while on patrol.
See March 2016 Medical Treatment Record- Non-Government Facility at 1.
In July 2016, VA psychiatrist, V.M. opined that the Veteran has chronic PTSD related to his military service.
See July 2016 Medical Treatment Record- Government Facility at 7.

In contrast with the opinions of the Veteran’s clinicians, following a VA examination an April 2016 VA psychologist opined that the Veteran does not have a current acquired psychiatric disorder consistent with the fifth edition of the diagnostic and statistics manual (DSM 5).
See April 2016 C&P Exam.
The examiner summarized that the Veteran was evaluated by the specialized outpatient PTSD program through VA in January 2014.
They concluded that his PTSD symptoms were sub-threshold and diagnosed him with anxiety disorder NOS.
He was subsequently referred to the Mental Health Clinic where he has seen by V.M., M.D. six times.
Dr. V.M. has diagnosed him with unspecified anxiety disorder.
The Veteran has also been attending weekly outpatient PTSD groups through Communicare, Inc.  for several years.
Letters from two of the group leaders, indicated that they have diagnosed him with PTSD.
The VA examiner noted that the Veteran’s reported trauma did appear to meet criterion A.

The stressors reported were almost being knocked unconscious as the result of a fuel pump hitting him in the mouth and witnessing what he thought were Viet Cong with four or five other individuals tied up and held as prisoners.
He denied direct combat experiences.

However, it was noted that he did not report the same stressor to the VA examiner that he did to his provider in 2014; i.e.  he did not report to the VA examiner that he got hit by a few mortars, missiles hit the compound a time or two.
Ultimately, there is evidence for and against the claim.
The Board will resolve reasonable doubt in the favor of the Veteran and grant entitlement to service connection for an acquired psychiatric disorder.

Citation Nr: 19160219
Decision Date: 08/06/19
Archive Date: 08/02/19
DOCKET NO. 1731465
DATE: August 6, 2019
ORDER
Entitlement to service connection for skin cancer is dismissed.
Entitlement to service connection for posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is granted.
FINDINGS OF FACT
In July 2019, prior to the promulgation of a decision in the appeal, the Veteran withdrew from appeal the issue of entitlement to service connection for skin cancer.
The evidence is at least evenly balanced as to whether the Veteran has been diagnosed as having PTSD based on a corroborated in-service stressor.
CONCLUSIONS OF LAW
The criteria for withdrawal of an appeal by the Veteran, as to the issue of entitlement to service connection for skin cancer, are met.
With reasonable doubt resolved in favor of the Veteran, the criteria for service connection for PTSD are met.
REASONS AND BASES FOR FINDINGS AND CONCLUSIONS
The Veteran served on active duty from June 1968 to May 1978.
These matters come before the Board of Veterans’ Appeals (Board) from an August 2013 rating decision.
The Veteran requested a Board hearing before a Veterans Law Judge on his June 2017 substantive appeal (VA Form 9).
He withdrew his hearing request in March 2019 (see a March 2019 statement from the Veteran’s representative).
I.
Withdrawal of Appeal
Entitlement to service connection for skin cancer
The Board may dismiss any appeal which fails to allege specific error of fact or law in the determination being appealed.
An appeal may be withdrawn as to any or all issues involved in the appeal at any time before the Board promulgates a decision.
Withdrawal may be made by the Veteran or by his or her authorized representative in writing or on the record at a hearing on appeal.
Id.

In the present case, the Veteran’s representative submitted a signed statement in July 2019 in which she indicated that the Veteran wished to withdraw his appeal with respect to the issue of entitlement to service connection for skin cancer.
This statement constitutes a valid withdrawal of the appeal, with respect to this issue.

See Delisio v. Shinseki, 25 Vet. App. 45, 57 (2011) (“withdrawal of a claim is only effective where the withdrawal is explicit, unambiguous, and done with a full understanding of the consequences of such action on the part of the claimant”).
The United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit has not addressed the criteria as to a written request to withdraw a claim.

See Acree v. O’Rourke, 891 F.3d 1009, fn. 2 (Fed. Cir. 2018) (“Resolution of Acree’s appeal turns on the requirements necessary for an effective oral withdrawal of a claim at a board hearing. We express no view on the criteria that must be satisfied when a veteran submits a written request to withdraw a claim”).
As the Veteran has withdrawn the appeal as to this issue, there remain no allegations of errors of fact or law for appellate consideration with regard to this issue.
Accordingly, the Board does not have jurisdiction to review this issue on appeal, and the appeal is dismissed.
II.
Service Connection
Entitlement to service connection for PTSD
Service connection will be granted if the evidence demonstrates that current disability resulted from an injury suffered or disease contracted in active military, naval, or air service.
Establishing service connection generally requires competent evidence of three things: (1) current disability; (2) in-service injury or disease; and (3) a relationship between the two.
Saunders v. Wilkie, 886 F.3d 1356, 1361 (Fed. Cir. 2018).

Consistent with this framework, service connection is warranted for a disease first diagnosed after service when all the evidence, including that pertinent to service, establishes that the disease was incurred in service.

Service connection for PTSD requires medical evidence diagnosing the condition in accordance with 38 C.F.R. § 4.125 (a); a link, established by medical evidence, between current symptoms and an in-service stressor; and credible supporting evidence that the claimed in-service stressor occurred.
When there is a current diagnosis of PTSD, the sufficiency of a claimed in-service stressor is presumed.
Cohen v. Brown, 10 Vet. App. 128, 144 (1997).
Nevertheless, credible evidence that the claimed in-service stressor actually occurred is still required.
Credible supporting evidence cannot consist solely of after-the-fact medical evidence containing an opinion as to a causal relationship between PTSD and service.
See Moreau v. Brown, 9 Vet. App. 389, 396 (1996).

When there is an approximate balance of positive and negative evidence regarding any issue material to the determination of a matter, the Secretary shall give the benefit of the doubt to the claimant.
38 U.S.C. § 5107; see also Gilbert v. Derwinski, 1 Vet. App. 49, 53 (1990).
In this case, the Veteran contends that he has current psychiatric disability that is related to various psychiatric stressors that occurred in service.
The Board finds, for the following reasons, that the evidence is at least evenly balanced as to whether the Veteran has current PTSD that is based on a corroborated in-service stressor.
The Veteran’s medical records, including an April 2014 VA mental health initial evaluation note, show he has a current diagnosis of PTSD.
He contends that his PTSD is due to various psychiatric stressors that occurred in service.
For instance, as pertinent to this decision, he has reported that he was stationed aboard the USS Gurke in the Gulf of Tonkin in August 1969.
During this time, his ship was operating in close proximity to the USS Bon Homme Richard and he witnessed the crash of a military A-4 aircraft while it was attempting to land on that ship.
The Veteran’s ship assisted in the search for survivors, but the search was unsuccessful.

In April 2013, the agency of original jurisdiction (AOJ) contacted the U.S. Army and Joint Services Records Research Center (JSRRC) and requested that it attempt to verify the Veteran’s reported stressor.
In May 2013, the JSRRC responded that it had reviewed the deck logs from the USS Gurke and the USS Bon Homme Richard.

The deck logs confirmed that on August 10, 1969 an aircraft exploded upon landing on the USS Bon Homme Richard, that the aircraft sank in 225 feet of water, and that the pilot was possibly in the water.
The USS Gurke was 2,000 yards astern of the USS Bon Homme Richard at the time of the crash and was detailed to search for the pilot.

Also, the Veteran has submitted information from “The Virtual Wall” website which indicates that a Navy pilot assigned to the USS Bon Homme Richard died in a plane crash on August 10, 1969 in the Gulf of Tonkin and that his body was not recovered.

Moreover, the Veteran’s service personnel records include a memorandum dated in June 1969 from the commanding officer of the USS Gurke to the Veteran, in which the Veteran was notified that he was temporarily appointed to the grade of lieutenant (junior grade).
In light of the above evidence, the Board concludes that the Veteran has a current diagnosis of PTSD and that there is credible supporting evidence that his reported stressor in service occurred.

Hence, the only remaining question is whether there is competent medical evidence of a nexus between his PTSD and his reported stressor in service involving the aircraft crash aboard the USS Bon Homme Richard.
In this regard, there is conflicting medical evidence as to whether his PTSD is related to this stressor.

The Board must analyze the credibility and probative value of the evidence, account for the evidence which it finds to be persuasive or unpersuasive, and provide the reasons for its rejection of any material evidence favorable to the Veteran.
See Gabrielson v. Brown, 7 Vet. App. 36, 39-40 (1994).
The Board may favor one medical opinion over another, provided an adequate statement of reasons or bases is provided.
See Owens v. Brown, 7 Vet. App. 429, 433 (1995).

The psychologist who conducted a June 2013 VA psychiatric examination reported that the Veteran’s reported stressor in service involving his witnessing of an aircraft crash was not adequate to support a diagnosis of PTSD.

The examiner did not provide a specific rationale for this opinion, but did explain in a medical opinion that accompanies the June 2013 examination report that the Veteran’s response to the reported aircraft crash in service seemed to be more a moral outrage or sense of ineffectualness in recovering the victim/victims of the crash episode.
Overall, the examiner did not feel that the Veteran’s symptoms rose “to a full PTSD syndrome,” but were rather more indicative of an anxiety disorder with obsessive-compulsive traits.

In January 2014, a VA psychologist reviewed the Veteran’s claims file and explained, in pertinent part, that his Vet Center treatment records (which reflect treatment for PTSD) did not include any references to the reported stressor of witnessing an aircraft crash aboard the USS Bon Homme Richard.

Although the reported aircraft crash in service had been confirmed subsequent to the June 2013 VA psychiatric examination, the Veteran did not make any mention of this stressor during his Vet Center treatment.
Rather, the Veteran identified another unrelated stressor in service as being his most traumatic experience.

Therefore, while the conceded stressor would meet Criterion A for a diagnosis of PTSD, none of the other symptoms (intrusion, dissociative reactions, persistent avoidance, negative alterations in cognitions and mood, alterations in arousal and reactivity) were evidenced in response to the stressor.
Therefore, the psychologist concluded that the Veteran did not meet the diagnostic criteria for PTSD related to his conceded military non-combat experience.

The psychiatrist who completed the April 2014 VA mental health initial evaluation note explained that the Veteran reported various psychiatric stressors in service, including witnessing an aircraft crash and burn.
As a result of these stressors, he experienced nightmares, flashbacks, social isolation, avoidance, and problems with anger.
The psychiatrist concluded that the Veteran met the DSM-5 criteria for a diagnosis of PTSD caused by “accumulated trauma.”
His symptoms included intrusive thoughts, nightmares, flashbacks, avoidance, hypervigilance, and emotional numbing.

The June 2013 and January 2014 opinions are of somewhat limited probative value because they are essentially solely based upon a finding that the Veteran did not experience symptoms of PTSD in response to his reported stressor in service involving an aircraft crash.

The April 2014 VA mental health initial evaluation note, however, reflects that he did experience various symptoms of PTSD (including intrusive thoughts, nightmares, flashbacks, avoidance, hypervigilance, and emotional numbing) and that he had PTSD which was caused by various in-service stressors (including the aircraft crash in service).

Although the psychiatrist who completed the April 2014 VA mental health initial evaluation note did not provide any detailed rationale for his conclusion, he nonetheless concluded based upon an examination of the Veteran and consideration of his reported history, that he had PTSD related to various stressors in service (including the aircraft crash that he witnessed in service).
The April 2014 opinion is therefore entitled to some probative weight.

See Monzingo v. Shinseki, 26 Vet. App. 97, 106 (2012) (the fact that the rationale provided by an examiner “did not explicitly lay out the examiner’s journey from the facts to a conclusion,” did not render the examination inadequate); Acevedo v. Shinseki, 25 Vet. App. 286, 294 (2012) (medical reports must be read as a whole and in the context of the evidence of record).

In light of the above evidence, the Board finds that the evidence is at least evenly balanced as to whether the Veteran’s PTSD is based on the corroborated in-service stressor involving an aircraft crash while stationed aboard the USS Gurke.

As the reasonable doubt created by this relative equipoise in the evidence must be resolved in favor of the Veteran, the criteria for service connection for PTSD are met and service connection for this disability is granted.
The Board points out that the benefit granted herein is service connection for PTSD.

Although the Veteran has been diagnosed as having other psychiatric disabilities during the claim period, including anxiety disorder and major depressive disorder, there is no evidence to distinguish between all of the symptoms of his psychiatric disabilities.
Therefore, a separate decision as to entitlement to service connection for psychiatric disability other than PTSD is unnecessary.

See Howell v. Nicholson, 19 Vet. App. 535, 540 (2006) (explaining that the Secretary must apply the benefit of the doubt doctrine and attribute the inseparable effects of a disability to the claimant’s service-connected disability).
Thus, in applying the benefit of the doubt doctrine, all of the Veteran’s psychiatric symptoms must, therefore, be attributed to his now service-connected PTSD.

See Mittleider v. West, 11 Vet. App. 181, 182 (1998) (VA must apply the benefit of the doubt doctrine and attribute the inseparable effects of a disability to the claimant’s service-connected disability).
Jonathan Hager
Veterans Law Judge
Board of Veterans’ Appeals
Attorney for the Board B. Elwood, Counsel
Citation Nr: 19154420
Decision Date: 07/16/19

DOCKET NO. 18-45 612
DATE: July 16, 2019
ORDER
Service connection for posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is denied.
Service connection for major depressive disorder (MDD) with psychotic features is denied.
Service connection for sleep apnea is denied.
Entitlement to total disability based on individual unemployability due to service-connected disabilities (TDIU) is denied.
FINDINGS OF FACT
The Veteran has current diagnosis of PTSD.
The claimed stressor did not involve combat or fear of hostile military or terrorist activity.
An in-service stressor sufficient to cause PTSD has not been verified or corroborated by evidence of record.
The Veteran has a current diagnosis of MDD.
The Veteran’s MDD did not begin in service and is not causally or etiologically related to service.
The Veteran does not have a current sleep apnea diagnosis.
Service connection has not been established for any disability.
CONCLUSIONS OF LAW
The criteria for service connection for PTSD have not been met.
The criteria for service connection for MDD have not been met.
The criteria for sleep apnea have not been met.
The criteria for a TDIU have not been met.
REASONS AND BASES FOR FINDINGS AND CONCLUSIONS
The Veteran served on active duty in the United States Navy from July 13, 1964 to August 21, 1964 in Peacetime and during the beginning of the Vietnam War Era.
After one and a half weeks of service and during Navy training, the Veteran had an asthma attack, which led to a medical discharge shortly thereafter.
This matter is before the Board of Veterans’ Appeals (Board) on appeal from two rating decisions (RDs), dated July 2015 and February 2017.
The July 2015 RD denied service connection for PTSD, and the February 2017 RD denied service connection for sleep apnea and TDIU.
The Veteran timely filed a June 2016 notice of disagreement regarding the PTSD claim, and an April 2017 notice of disagreement regarding the sleep apnea and TDIU claims.
Two statements of the case (SOC) were issued in August 2018, denying all three claims, and the Veteran substantively appealed the three claims in September 2018.
The appeal was certified to the Board in October 2018, and the Veteran declined a Board hearing.
This matter now is timely before the Board for disposition.

The Board here recharacterizes the PTSD claim to include an additional claim for service connection for a psychiatric disorder other than PTSD—major depressive disorder—in accordance with the United States Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims.

See Clemons v. Shinseki, 23 Vet. App. 1 (2009) (holding that a claim for benefits for one psychiatric disability also encompassed benefits based on other psychiatric diagnoses and should be considered by the Board to be within the scope of the filed claim).
In March and May 2019 letters, the Veteran’s attorney informed VA that he had not received the January 2019 notice of docketing or the two August 2018 SOCs by mail.
The attorney further stated that he became aware of the filings after he reviewed VA’s case filing system, VBMS.
He requested that VA note an address change, of which he had previously informed VA.
As the attorney now has seen the documents, the Veteran has not been prejudiced.
In the March 2019 letter, the attorney waived a 90-day hold for additional evidence submission.
Service Connection Legal Criteria
Direct service connection may be granted for a disability resulting from disease or injury incurred in or aggravated by active service.
Service connection may be granted for any disease diagnosed after discharge, when all the evidence, including that pertinent to service, establishes that the disease was incurred in service.

Service connection generally requires (1) medical evidence of a current disability; (2) medical or, in certain circumstances, lay evidence of in-service incurrence or aggravation of a disease or injury; and (3) medical evidence of a nexus between the claimed in-service disease or injury and the current disability.
Secondary service connection may be established for a disability that is proximately due to or the result of service-connected disease or injury.
In such instance, service connection shall be granted as secondary to the disability for which VA benefits were initially established.
38 C.F.R. § 3.310(a); see Harder v. Brown, 5 Vet. App. 183, 187 (1993).
The Veteran may also obtain compensation for the aggravation of a nonservice-connected condition by a service-connected disability.
See 38 C.F.R. § 3.310(a); see Allen v. Brown, 7 Vet. App. 439, 448 (1995).

To prevail under a theory of secondary service causation, the record must show (1) evidence of a current disability, (2) evidence of a service-connected disability, and (3) medical nexus evidence establishing a connection between the current disability and the service-connected disability.
Wallin v. West, 11 Vet. App. 509, 512 (1998); Reiber v. Brown, 7 Vet. App. 513, 516-17 (1995).

Any increase in the severity of a nonservice-connected disability that is proximately due to or the result of a service-connected disease or injury, and not due to the natural progress of the nonservice-connected disability, will be itself service connected.

Service connection for PTSD requires the following three elements: (1) a current medical diagnosis of PTSD (presumed to include the adequacy of the PTSD symptomatology and the sufficiency of a claimed in-service stressor in accordance with 38 C.F.R. § 4.125(a)); (2) credible supporting evidence that the claimed in-service stressor occurred; and (3) medical evidence of a causal relationship between the current symptomatology and the specific claimed in-service stressor.

In adjudicating a claim for service connection for PTSD, the Board is required to evaluate evidence based on places, types, and circumstances of service, as shown by military records and all pertinent medical and lay evidence.
See Hayes v. Brown, 5 Vet. App. 60, 66 (1993); see also 38 U.S.C. § 1154(a); 38 C.F.R. § 3.304(f).
The evidence necessary to establish the occurrence of an in-service stressor for PTSD will vary depending on if the veteran "engaged in combat with the enemy."
Id.

If a veteran did not engage in combat with the enemy, or the claimed stressors are not related to combat, and the stressor is not related to fear of hostile military or terrorist activity, then the veteran’s testimony alone is not sufficient to establish the occurrence of the claimed stressors, and his testimony must be corroborated by credible supporting evidence.
Cohen v. Brown, 10 Vet. App. 128 (1997); Moreau v. Brown, 9 Vet. App. 389 (1996); Dizoglio v. Brown, 9 Vet. App. 163 (1996).
Furthermore, service department records must support, and not contradict, the claimant’s testimony regarding non-combat stressors.
Doran v. Brown, 6 Vet. App. 283 (1994).

Under 38 C.F.R. § 3.304(f)(5), if a PTSD claim is based on in-service personal assault, evidence from sources other than the veteran's service records may corroborate the veteran's account of the stressor incident.

Examples of such evidence include, but are not limited to: records from law enforcement authorities, rape crisis centers, mental health counseling centers, hospitals, or physicians; pregnancy tests or tests for sexually transmitted diseases; and statements from family members, roommates, fellow service members, or clergy.
Evidence of behavior changes following the claimed assault is one type of relevant evidence that may be found in these sources.

Examples of behavior changes that may constitute credible evidence of the stressor include, but are not limited to: a request for a transfer to another military duty assignment; deterioration in work performance; substance abuse; episodes of depression, panic attacks, or anxiety without an identifiable cause; or unexplained economic or social behavior changes.

The question of whether a veteran was exposed to a stressor in service is a factual one, and VA adjudicators are not bound to accept uncorroborated accounts of stressors or medical opinions based upon such accounts.
Wood v. Derwinski, 1 Vet. App. 190 (1991), aff’d on reconsideration, 1 Vet. App. 406 (1991).
Hence, whether a stressor was of sufficient gravity to cause or support a diagnosis of PTSD is a question of fact for medical professionals.
Whether the evidence establishes the occurrence of stressors, however, is a question of fact for adjudicators.

PTSD, MDD, and sleep apnea are not “chronic diseases” under 38 C.F.R. § 3.309(a); therefore, the presumptive provisions of 38 C.F.R. § 3.303(b) for "chronic" in service symptoms and "continuous" post-service symptoms do not apply.
Walker v. Shinseki, 708 F.3d 1331 (Fed. Cir. 2013).
Denial of Service Connection for PTSD
The Veteran asserts that he witnessed an in-service stressor—the accidental drowning of a fellow soldier during training—which caused his current PTSD.

The Veteran reported to the VA that, shortly after beginning his Naval training in July 1964 at the Recruit Training Command (RTC) in Great Lakes, Illinois, he witnessed the drowning of another trainee during an aquatic training exercise.
Specifically, he reported that he saw the trainee in the pool in distress with blood in the water.
The next day, the Veteran heard that the trainee had died.
After a review of the record, the Board finds that service connection for PTSD is not warranted because the claimed in-service stressor has not been sufficiently verified.
An in-service personal assault like the one described by the Veteran must be supported or verified by credible supporting evidence.
The stressor event claimed by the Veteran has not been sufficiently verified or corroborated by evidence in the record, as required under 38 C.F.R. § 3.304(f)(5).
The evidence includes a diagnosis of PTSD.
See Mental Health Treatment Records.

The statements in the record from treating mental health professionals regarding the Veteran’s PTSD, which simply record the history as told to them by the Veteran, are not sufficient to corroborate the stressor.

The recorded histories relied only on the Veteran’s recent reporting of the claimed in-service event asserted to be a stressor, and the recent examination reports did not include independent verification of the claimed stressor event.
The military service personnel records and service treatment records (STRs) do not include any reports or even oblique references to a drowning accident.
During the Veteran’s very brief time in the Navy, he experienced an asthma attack, which led to review by a Medical Board and a subsequent discharge for unfitness for service.
See STRs and Military Personnel Records.
In support of his VA PTSD claim, the Veteran reported that his asthma attacked happened the day after witnessing the drowning, implying that stress caused the asthma attack.

None of the contemporaneous medical records from 1964, however, note reports from the Veteran of the drowning or any psychiatric or psychological symptoms such as stress, fear, or guilt in the context of his asthma attack or otherwise.

If stress had caused his asthma attack, it is likely that he would have reported that to the treating physician and the Medical Board, especially considering that the Medical Board was considering fitness for service.

See Curry v. Brown, 7 Vet. App. 59 (1994) (noting that contemporaneous evidence has greater probative value than history as reported by the veteran); Kahana v. Shinseki, 24 Vet. App. 428, 440 (2011) (Lance, J., concurring) (the silence in a medical record can be weighed against lay testimony if the alleged injury, disease, or related symptoms would ordinarily have been recorded in the medical record being evaluated by the fact finder).

The August 1964 Report from the Medical Board found that the Veteran had not disclosed his history of asthma (and asthma attacks) on his enlistment documents, and if he had done so, he would not have been found fit for service.
As such, the Medical Board recommended (and the commander agreed and implemented) a discharged by reason of erroneous enlistment.

Additionally, VA conducted a Joint Service Records Research Center search to attempt to verify the claimed stressor, which was negative for any military records regarding a drowning or death in 1964, as described by the Veteran.

The search included a review of the 1964 command histories submitted by both RTC and the Naval Training Command located in Great Lakes, Illinois, as well as a review of the Department of Defense casualty reports available and coordinated with the Casualty Assistance Division, Navy Personnel Command in Millington, Tennessee.
Finally, an additional search by the Naval Criminal Investigative Service also yielded no results.
A trainee drowning during a naval training exercise is the sort of incident which would have been documented and investigated by the command at the time of the incident.

In support of the PTSD claim, the Veteran submitted a July 2015 lay statement represented to be from a high school friend and fellow recruit (through the buddy program), who was stationed with the Veteran in Great Lakes, Michigan.

The statement asserts that the friend also witnessed the drowning of a trainee; that prior to service the Veteran was outgoing, social, and happy about his future in the Navy, but the Veteran changed after service, becoming sad, frightened, and disillusioned with his future.
The friend did not provide any current contact information and noted that he had not spoken about the incident until his friend asked him to in the context of the VA claim.

While the Veteran’s friend stated that a drowning happened during their naval training which negatively impacted his friend (and himself), the statement was made many years after the incident, lacks specific details about the event, and omitted contact information; thus, the Board finds that the statement is of minimal probative value in the context of reporting a drowning event for which there is no independent military documentation or corroboration.

Given the Veteran’s lack of contemporaneous reporting of the stressor (the first reference of the stressor in the record is from almost 50 years later and close in time to his VA claim for compensation), his misrepresentation of his health on the enlistment documents, the lack of military records documenting the incident, and absence of any military record references to death of a recruit, the Board finds that the evidence has not corroborated or verified the claimed stressor.
As such, the Board finds that the reported event alleged to be the stressor is not corroborated.

Accordingly, upon consideration of all information and lay and medical evidence of record in this matter, the Board finds that the preponderance of the evidence is against service connection for PTSD.
Denial of Service Connection for MDD
To the extent that the Veteran has been diagnosed with MDD in addition to PTSD, the Board also considered whether the  MDD could be service connected as a separate claim from PTSD.
The MDD includes PTSD-like symptoms and other psychiatric symptoms experienced by the Veteran for the entire appeal period.
See Mental Health Treatment Records.
After a review of the evidence, the Board finds that service connection for MDD is not warranted.
While the Veteran has a current MDD diagnosis, the Board finds that the MDD did not begin in service and is not causally or etiologically related to service.

The STRs do not include any psychiatric complaints or symptoms, and no diagnoses. Furthermore, the record does not include any MDD or other psychiatric diagnosis, any psychiatric treatment records, or any assertions of a psychiatric disorder for VA purposes until the Veteran asserted a PTSD claim in 2013—almost 50 years after discharge from service in 1964.

As discussed above, MDD is not a chronic disease under the chronic disease presumption for service connection. While the MDD diagnosis includes psychotic features in some of the mental health treatment records, the Veteran has not been diagnosed with a psychosis, which would be a chronic disease for VA purposes.

In any event, the STRs do not show any psychiatric symptoms in service, and the record as a whole does not show that any psychiatric disorder manifested to 10 percent within one year of service or that psychiatric symptoms have been continuous since service.

While the Veteran has asserted that he experienced psychiatric symptoms in and since service, the Board finds the lack of lay or medical evidence of such symptoms for almost 50 years to be highly persuasive.

As discussed above in detail, the record does not support the Veteran’s recent statements about his asserted PTSD stressor, nor does it show any contemporaneous psychiatric symptoms or diagnoses prior to 2013, when the Veteran first asserted PTSD for purposes of VA compensation.

Accordingly, upon consideration of all information and lay and medical evidence of record in this matter, the Board finds that the preponderance of the evidence is against entitlement to service connection for MDD on a direct or presumptive basis, and the claim must be denied.
Denial of Service Connection of Sleep Apnea, to Include as Secondary to PTSD
The Veteran contends that sleep apnea is related to PTSD.
In this decision, the Board is denying service connection for PTSD.

After a review of the evidence, the Board finds that direct service connection for sleep apnea is not warranted because the weight of the evidence shows no symptoms of sleep apnea during service and no current diagnosis of sleep apnea.
The weight of the evidence demonstrates that sleep apnea did not begin in service and is not otherwise related to service.
There are no STRs noting any diagnoses, complaints of, or treatment for, sleep apnea or any other sleep impairments.
The weight of the evidence shows that the Veteran does not have a current sleep apnea diagnosis.
See VA Mental Health Treatment Records.
A November 2016 VA mental health treatment record noted that sleep apnea was suspected and indicated that the Veteran would participate in a sleep study.
A January 2017 VA mental health treatment record noted that the Veteran reported that he had a sleep study, but did not yet have the results.
Nowhere in the record does the Veteran report a sleep apnea diagnosis or date of diagnosis.

To the extent that the Veteran asserts that sleep apnea was caused by the current PTSD, because the Board has denied service for PTSD or any other psychological disorder, so there is no primary service-connected disability to which sleep apnea could be related, secondary service connection is precluded as a matter of law.
For these reasons, the claim for service connection for sleep apnea must be denied.
Denial of Entitlement to TDIU
The Veteran contends that he is entitled to TDIU due to PTSD.
As service connection for PTSD has been denied, and service connection has not been established for any disability, a TDIU is precluded as a matter of law.

ORDER
Entitlement to service connection for posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is granted.
FINDINGS OF FACT
1. The Veteran has a current diagnosis of PTSD.
2. The evidence establishes that the Veteran experienced an in-service personal assault.
3. The competent and probative evidence of record establishes that the Veteran’s PTSD is casually related to service.
CONCLUSION OF LAW
The criteria for service connection for PTSD have been met.
REASONS AND BASES FOR FINDINGS AND CONCLUSION
The Veteran served honorably in the Marine Corps from September 1975 to September 1979.
This matter comes before the Board of Veterans’ Appeals (Board) on appeal from an April 2014 rating decision by a Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) Regional Office (RO).
Entitlement to service connection for an acquired psychiatric condition, to include PTSD.

The Veteran contends he is entitled to service connection for an acquired psychiatric condition, to include PTSD, based on an in-service stressor where the Veteran was struck by his drill instructor, throwing the Veteran’s face into the butt of his rifle, knocking out his two front teeth.
Service connection may be granted for disability resulting from disease or injury incurred in or aggravated by active service.

The three-element test for service connection requires evidence of: (1) a current disability; (2) in-service incurrence or aggravation of a disease or injury; and (3) a causal relationship between the current disability and the in-service disease or injury.
Shedden v. Principi, 381 F.3d 1163, 1166-67 (Fed. Cir. 2004).

Service connection for PTSD, specifically, requires: (1) medical evidence establishing a diagnosis of the disability in accordance with 38 C.F.R. § 4.125(a); (2) credible supporting evidence that the claimed in-service stressor actually occurred; and (3) a link, established by medical evidence, between the current symptomatology and the claimed in-service stressor.

Where a determination is made that the veteran did not “engage in combat with the enemy,” or the claimed stressor is unrelated to combat, the veteran’s lay testimony alone will not be enough to establish the occurrence of the alleged stressor.
See Moreau v. Brown, 9 Vet. App. 389, 395 (1996);  Dizoglio v. Brown, 9 Vet. App. 163, 166 (1996).
In such cases, the record must include service records or other credible evidence that supports and does not contradict the veteran’s testimony.
Doran v. Brown, 6 Vet. App. 283, 289 (1994).
Moreover, a medical opinion diagnosing PTSD does not suffice to verify the occurrence of the claimed in-service stressors.
See Moreau, 9 Vet. App. at 395-96;  Cohen v. Brown, 10 Vet. App. 128, 142 (1997).
However, if a PTSD claim is based on in-service personal assault, evidence from sources other than the veteran’s service records may corroborate the veteran’s account of the stressor incident.

Examples of such evidence include, but are not limited to: records from law enforcement authorities, rape crisis centers, mental health counseling centers, hospitals, or physicians, and statements from family members, roommates, fellow service members, or clergy.

Behavioral changes following the claims assault, including substance abuse, episodes of depression, panic attacks, or anxiety without an identifiable cause, and unexplained economic or social behaviors are also relevant pieces of evidence supporting the existence of an in-service stressor.
Id.

The Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims has set a relatively low bar for interpreting a claim for PTSD as one involving a personal assault stressor for which the provisions of 38 C.F.R. § 3.304(f)(5) are applicable.
See Bradford v. Nicholson, 20 Vet. App. 200 (2006) (veteran alleged that his drill sergeant kicked him down a set of stairs).
As applied to this Veteran’s claim, the Board finds his allegation of being struck in the face by his drill instructor meets the definition for personal assault.
Turning now to the elements of service connection for PTSD and applying them to the Veteran’s claim, the Board first finds competent medical evidence of a current disability.
To that end, the Veteran underwent his first positive PTSD screening at a VA facility in July 2013 and was subsequently diagnosed with PTSD in August 2015.

This diagnosis is further supported by a private psychological examination conducted in March 2016, which again yielded a diagnosis of chronic PTSD, according to the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-V).

Accordingly, the Board finds that competent medical evidence establishes a diagnosis of PTSD in accordance with 38 C.F.R. § 4.125(a), such that the first element required to establish service connection for PTSD has been met.
The Board also finds that evidence on record supports finding that the Veteran’s claimed in-service stressor actually occurred.
Evidence as to the actual event comes from eye-witness statements made by a fellow service member, as well as the Veteran’s service treatment records.

The fellow service member, who was a recruit at the same time as the Veteran, stated that as he stood across from the Veteran, he saw the Veteran’s drill instructor strike the Veteran in the face and the Veteran spit out his front teeth.

Moreover, the Veteran’s service dental records document treatment on his eighth and ninth teeth—his two front teeth—around the same time the Veteran states he was struck in the face, dislodging these teeth.
While the Veteran’s entrance examination report indicates his two front teeth were removable partial dentures, the Veteran contends these were in fact permanently replaced teeth.
Nevertheless, the fact the Veteran did not have two real front teeth does not diminish that he was struck in the face by his drill instructor, which is the claimed stressor.
Evidence of behavioral changes supporting the in-service stressor come from statements made by the Veteran’s sister.
She notes a dramatic shift in behavior following the Veteran’s time in the Marine Corps.
She states that prior to service, the Veteran was social, outgoing, funny, and “an all around nice guy.”
However, she states that following service, the Veteran has been easily irritable, argumentative and confrontational, has lacked trust in others, and has socially isolated himself.
According to his sister, upon return, the Veteran rarely even attended family events, despite living nearby and having regularly done so in the past.

Accordingly, with an eye-witness statement, service treatment records, and noted behavioral changes pointing toward the existence of this in-service stressor, the Board finds the second element of service connection for PTSD has been met.
The Board also finds medical evidence on record establishes a link between the Veteran’s current disability and the in-service stressor.
The link stems from the March 2016 private psychological evaluation.
The psychologist discusses the Veteran’s pre-military, military, and post-military histories, his presenting symptoms, and the tests conducted to determine the appropriate diagnoses.

The psychologist notes that “the [V]eteran’s answers to the PTSD Symptoms Checklist indicate he always experiences intrusive memories of Paris Island and the surprise attack [by his drill instructor],” and that “[the Veteran’s] present difficulties are attributed directly to his experiences in the military.”
As such, the Board finds that competent medical evidence establishes a link between the Veteran’s military service and his current PTSD and that the third element has been met.

The Board acknowledges that a psychological evaluation submitted in March 2019, but conducted in July 2018, notes that the Veteran is diagnosed with major depressive disorder with PTSD and anxiety features.
The opinion is probative and raises a reasonable doubt as to whether the Veteran is currently suffering from major depressive disorder or PTSD primarily.

However, in resolving all reasonable doubt in the Veteran’s favor, the Board finds that the evidence supports that the Veteran has a current diagnosis of PTSD, especially considering the major depressive disorder diagnosis carried with it PTSD features.

To that effect, the presence of a chronic disability at any time during or immediately preceding the claims process can justify a grant of service connection, even where the most recent diagnosis is negative, which is not the case here.

McClain v. Nicholson, 21 Vet. App. 319 (2007);  Romanowski v. Shinseki, 26 Vet. App. 289, 294 (2013) (holding the current disability requirement may be satisfied by evidence of the disability shortly before the claim is filed).
Accordingly, resolving all doubt in favor of the Veteran, the Board finds service connection is warranted in this case.
